contentrichtext.text: '''Supergalactic coordinates''' are [[coordinates]] in a [[spherical coordinate system]] which was designed to have its [[equator]] aligned with the '''supergalactic plane''', a major structure in the local universe formed by the preferential distribution of nearby [[galaxy cluster]]s (such as the [[Virgo cluster]], the [[Great Attractor]] and the [[Pisces-Perseus supercluster]]) towards a (two-dimensional) [[plane (mathematics)|plane]]. The supergalactic plane was recognized by [[Gérard de Vaucouleurs]] in 1953 from the [[Shapley-Ames catalogue]], although a flattened distribution of [[nebula]]e had been noted by [[William Herschel]] over 200 years earlier. By convention, supergalactic latitude and supergalactic longitude are usually denoted by SGB and SGL, respectively, by analogy to ''b'' and ''l'' conventionally used for [[galactic coordinates]]. The zero point for supergalactic longitude is defined by the intersection of this plane with the galactic plane. ==Definition== *The north supergalactic pole (SGB=90°) lies at galactic coordinates (''l'' =47.37°, ''b'' =+6.32°). In the [[equatorial coordinate system]] ([[epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] [[J2000]]), this is approximately ([[right ascension|RA]]=18.9 h, [[declination|Dec]]=+15.7°). *The zero point (SGB=0°, SGL=0°) lies at (''l''=137.37°, ''b''=0°). In J2000 equatorial coordinates, this is approximately (2.82 h, +59.5°). ==See also== *[[Coordinate system]] *[[Celestial coordinate system]] ==External references== *[http://cdsads.u-strasbg.fr/cgi-bin/nph-data_query?bibcode=2000MNRAS.312..166L&db_key=AST&link_type=ARTICLE Precise definition by Lahav et al. 2000, MNRAS, 312, 166] {{Celestial coordinate systems}} {{Galaxy}} [[Category:Celestial coordinate system]] [[Category:Extragalactic astronomy]]
